title: How to Make a Complete Lebanese Dinner

steps.headline: Ingredients:
steps.description: Three bunches of fresh parsley One large mixing bowl ½ cup bulgar (cracked wheat) Measuring cups 2 cups water Cutting board and knife 1 bunch green onions One small mixing bowl 2 large red tomatoes ¼ cup fresh mint 1 ½ teaspoon salt ½ teaspoon pepper 1/3 cup fresh squeezed lemon juice ¼ cup olive oil.

steps.headline: To begin, wash all your fresh vegetables.

Take the bulgar and pour it into the small mixing bowl, adding the two cups of water and let sit for approximately fifteen minutes, or until the bulgar has soaked up the majority of the water and somewhat resembles couscous or quinoa.
steps.description: Always pour just enough water to barely cover the bulgar, and no more because we do not want to soften the bulgar too much.

steps.headline: While your bulgar is soaking, take your fresh parsley and remove the stems.
steps.description: Chop the leaves very finely and place in large mixing bowl.

steps.headline: Now returning to your bulgar after the fifteen minutes is through, cup the cracked wheat into your hand and strain the excess water.
steps.description: Then place bulgar in large mixing bowl with parsley

steps.headline: You may now begin mincing the mint leaves, and chopping your green onions and tomatoes into small pieces.
Note that generally the onions, tomatoes and mint leaves are chopped finely, but this is also up to the cook in regards to how finely they wish for the ingredients to be diced.
steps.description: But remember, no matter the look or outcome, if you follow the procedure, the food will taste the same, even if it has a different consistency.

steps.headline: Add the chopped tomatoes, onions, mint leaves to large bowl mixture.
Pour lemon juice and olive oil into large bowl.
Mix all ingredients together very well.
Add salt and pepper to large bowl and continue to mix all the ingredients.
If needed, if the tabbouleh looks dry add more lemon juice or olive oil.
steps.description: It must not be dry.

steps.headline: Note that this is where the cook must decide if more of any other ingredient is necessary: bulgar, tomato, lemons, salt, etc…
Place in fridge and let sit overnight for the following day.
The following day, mix again before serving the dish cold.
Ingredients:
steps.description: 1 can/jar grape leaves 1 ½ cups long-grain white rice 2 minced onions 2 tablespoons dried currant 2 tablespoons pine nuts 1 tablespoon cinnamon 1 tablespoon mint 1 teaspoon all spice 1 teaspoon olive oil 5 tablespoons fresh squeezed lemon juice (more if necessary) One large mixing bowl Knife and cutting board Water, One boiling pot One large skillet One heat resistant bowl One steamer pot

steps.headline: Begin by boiling several cups of water over the stovetop and turn your steamer pot on as well.
Taking the grape leaves, drain them of their excess fluids and place in heat resistant bowl.
NOTE: Grape leaves can be found in a can, which is often risky since you cannot see the grape leaf, or in a glass jar, in which case you will be able to see the thickness or thinness of the leaf.
steps.description: The thinner the leaf, the better, because when a leaf has thick veins it makes the final result very stringy to eat.

steps.headline: Pour just enough hot water over the leaves so that the fluids cover the leaves barely, like the bulgar with the tabbouleh and let soak for approximately 20 minutes.
Mince onions, pine nuts and dried currants.
Take skillet, add olive oil and toss the onions in as well to lightly brown them.
steps.description: Add the rice along with enough water to cover and cook the rice mixture.

steps.headline: Turn off heat, add dried currants, pine nuts and spices: cinnamon, mint, and all spice.
steps.description: Let mixture cool.

steps.headline: Now removing your grape leaves from the hot water, rinse them and begin to remove the stems.
When your rice mixture is cooled down, take about one-two teaspoons (depending on the size of your leaves) and place in center of the leaf.
steps.description: The stem of the leaf should be facing down towards you. Begin folding the leaf, taking the left side and folding it inwards towards the stem and the same goes to the right. Now roll the leaf up towards the tip like it were a tortilla to engulf the mixture and created what looks like an enclosed burrito.

steps.headline: CAUTION: Make sure to roll the leaf tight enough to where the dolmas will not fall apart when picked up to eat.
steps.description: The whole purpose of wrapping the mixture is to keep it together, like a cigar, and have the flavor of the grape leaves compliment the roll as well.

steps.headline: After rolling all the mixture into the leaves, take your rolls and place them in the steamer pot.
steps.description: Add water in the steamer cover to preserve moisture and let them sit for 30-45 minutes, or until rice is cooked.

steps.headline: Remove dolmas from steamer and immediately pour lemon juice onto the leaves and place in refrigerator to serve cold, or even at room temperature if pressed for time.
Ingredients:
steps.description: 2 lbs lean ground lamb (or substitute with lean ground beef) ½ cup bulgar (cracked wheat) ¼ teaspoon cinnamon 1 teaspoon salt frying pan teaspoon pepper olive oil 1 teaspoon allspice cutting board and knife ¼ teaspoon ground cumin 2 mixing bowls 2 medium sized onions paper towels and plate ½ cup pine nuts 2 cups water

steps.headline: Make sure your meat is thawed out and fresh.
Take the bulgar and water like before, place in small bowl and let sit for 15-20 minutes or depending on the absorbency rate of the cracked wheat.
Begin cutting your onions, some minced and some chopped, and set aside.
NOTE: The following step is optional; as you may either cook the ingredients 	all together at once, or lightly pan fry piece by piece.
Take your frying pan, set on medium heat.
steps.description: Add a teaspoon of olive oil, and lightly brown the onions and pine nuts. Be careful not to burn as they will be cooked again into the meat. Remove onions and pine nuts and let cool.

steps.headline: Return to your bulgar after the allotted time and strain any excess water from the cracked wheat and set aside.
Now, in the other mixing bowl, combine salt, pepper, all spice (or kibbeh all spices that may be found at local Arabic store or market), and ground cumin.
At this point, your bulgar is prepared, your meat is thawed, your spices are mixed and the onions and pine nuts are either ready for cooking or have already been lightly browned.
steps.description: Take a handful of meat, like you were making a hamburger patty and mix onions, pine nuts, bulgar and spices into the meat. Very similar to seasoning hamburgers or any other types of meat. Keep rolling the ingredients and press the meat lightly together as it’s sometimes difficult to mix these ingredients into your lamb or beef. The size of each kibbeh “patty” is to your own choice, but keep in mind the thicker the meat, the longer the time it takes to cook.

steps.headline: Your oven should be set on medium-high now, ready to pan fry lots of meat.

NOTE: Some kibbeh recipes opt for baking the meat instead of pan frying, while others are form their meat entirely different, almost in the shape of a torpedo – filled with spices and then deep fried.
steps.description: This recipe is clearly not the only means of cooking kibbeh. Be reminded this is only one method.

steps.headline: Place two teaspoons of olive oil into the pan, or a little less depending on the size as you do not want to soak the meat in too much oil.
steps.description: Take about four patties of meat, or however many your pan will contain, and begin to pan fry the patties.

steps.headline: Occasionally roll the patty over from side to side, in order to cook the meat thoroughly and flake the remaining spices over the meat while its cooking.
The meat will brown very dark, almost like its burnt but this is the cumin, all spice and cinnamon darkening the meat.
steps.description: However, if its turning black or smoking, or smells like its burning, you are obviously running the meat and need to lower the heat of the oven or add more oil for moisture.

steps.headline: Take your plate, and place a few paper towels over the plate to cover it and set close to the stove.
After each patty is finished, place the meat onto the paper towels to let excess oils strain from the kibbeh.
steps.description: Let cool, but serve while its still hot. Often kibbeh is served with plan yogurt, or homemade style yogurt that dates back centuries.

steps.headline: Preparing a full Lebanese dinner, especially for beginners, is no easy task.
steps.description: Often the hardest part is gathering all the materials together. Be reminded that appearance is not essential for this kind of food, granted you do not want to look unappetizing or spoiled, but taste is much more important. Be patient when cooking these foods, and take your time. Perhaps try making each dish separately before taking the ambition to cook all four recipes all at once. Or make it an evening affair and invite your friends over to try something new. But, once you are accustomed to the routine and demand of cooking and baking Lebanese cuisine, you will have no problems adjusting to other styles of Mediterranean foods and become eager to know more.

steps.headline: Ingredients:
steps.description: 1 lb frozen phyllo sheets 1 cup melted butter 2 cups finely chopped walnuts 2 cups finely chopped blanched almonds 3 cups sugar ½ teaspoon ground cinnamon ¾ cup honey 1 tablespoon lemon juice One large baking pan One mixing bowl One large knife,One boiling pot

steps.headline: Lightly grease baking pan with butter, if you forget this step, your dessert will be ruined, as the phyllo sheets will stick to the pan.
steps.description: Also pre-heat your oven to 400 degrees.

steps.headline: Thaw phyllo pastry, and taking four sheets of the pastry, use the melted butter to brush and soften each sheet.
steps.description: Place half of the butter brushed sheets into baking pan.

steps.headline: Mix nuts, ½ cup sugar and cinnamon in a bowl.
steps.description: Sprinkle  a third of the mixture over pastry sheets lying in the baking pan.

steps.headline: Take an additional two phyllo pastry sheets and brush them with butter like before, and place the remaining sheets above the mixture poured into the baking pan.
Continue to add another layer of more nut and sugar mixture.
steps.description: Repeat steps 4 and 5 until there are only four remaining phyllo sheets.

steps.headline: Taking the last four phyllo sheets, brush them with butter, except for the top layer and place them into the baking pan and tuck away any overlapping.
Take a large knife and cut the sheet into squares, traditional diamond shaped pieces.
Place baking pan into the oven and set time for 30 minutes or until golden brown.
While the dessert is in the oven, combine ¾ cup sugar, honey, one cup water and lemon juice into pot and wait for it to boil.
Boil baklava syrup for about 20 minutes, occasionally stirring until the consistency is like a maple or waffle syrup like texture.
As soon as the baklava is done, remove it from the oven and immediately pour the syrup all over the dessert.
Allow the baklava to cool about 3-4 hours and to also absorb the syrup before serving and enjoy!

text: Tabbouleh Ingredients: Three bunches of fresh parsley One large mixing bowl ½ cup bulgar (cracked wheat) Measuring cups 2 cups water Cutting board and knife 1 bunch green onions One small mixing bowl 2 large red tomatoes ¼ cup fresh mint 1 ½ teaspoon salt ½ teaspoon pepper 1/3 cup fresh squeezed lemon juice ¼ cup olive oil. To begin, wash all your fresh vegetables.  Take the bulgar and pour it into the small mixing bowl, adding the two cups of water and let sit for approximately fifteen minutes, or until the bulgar has soaked up the majority of the water and somewhat resembles couscous or quinoa. Always pour just enough water to barely cover the bulgar, and no more because we do not want to soften the bulgar too much. While your bulgar is soaking, take your fresh parsley and remove the stems. Chop the leaves very finely and place in large mixing bowl. Now returning to your bulgar after the fifteen minutes is through, cup the cracked wheat into your hand and strain the excess water. Then place bulgar in large mixing bowl with parsley You may now begin mincing the mint leaves, and chopping your green onions and tomatoes into small pieces.  Note that generally the onions, tomatoes and mint leaves are chopped finely, but this is also up to the cook in regards to how finely they wish for the ingredients to be diced. But remember, no matter the look or outcome, if you follow the procedure, the food will taste the same, even if it has a different consistency. Add the chopped tomatoes, onions, mint leaves to large bowl mixture.  Pour lemon juice and olive oil into large bowl.  Mix all ingredients together very well.  Add salt and pepper to large bowl and continue to mix all the ingredients.  If needed, if the tabbouleh looks dry add more lemon juice or olive oil. It must not be dry. Note that this is where the cook must decide if more of any other ingredient is necessary: bulgar, tomato, lemons, salt, etc…  Place in fridge and let sit overnight for the following day.  The following day, mix again before serving the dish cold.  Dolmas (Stuffed Grape Leaves) Ingredients: 1 can/jar grape leaves 1 ½ cups long-grain white rice 2 minced onions 2 tablespoons dried currant 2 tablespoons pine nuts 1 tablespoon cinnamon 1 tablespoon mint 1 teaspoon all spice 1 teaspoon olive oil 5 tablespoons fresh squeezed lemon juice (more if necessary) One large mixing bowl Knife and cutting board Water, One boiling pot One large skillet One heat resistant bowl One steamer pot Begin by boiling several cups of water over the stovetop and turn your steamer pot on as well.  Taking the grape leaves, drain them of their excess fluids and place in heat resistant bowl.  NOTE: Grape leaves can be found in a can, which is often risky since you cannot see the grape leaf, or in a glass jar, in which case you will be able to see the thickness or thinness of the leaf. The thinner the leaf, the better, because when a leaf has thick veins it makes the final result very stringy to eat. Pour just enough hot water over the leaves so that the fluids cover the leaves barely, like the bulgar with the tabbouleh and let soak for approximately 20 minutes.  Mince onions, pine nuts and dried currants.  Take skillet, add olive oil and toss the onions in as well to lightly brown them. Add the rice along with enough water to cover and cook the rice mixture. Turn off heat, add dried currants, pine nuts and spices: cinnamon, mint, and all spice. Let mixture cool. Now removing your grape leaves from the hot water, rinse them and begin to remove the stems.  When your rice mixture is cooled down, take about one-two teaspoons (depending on the size of your leaves) and place in center of the leaf. The stem of the leaf should be facing down towards you. Begin folding the leaf, taking the left side and folding it inwards towards the stem and the same goes to the right. Now roll the leaf up towards the tip like it were a tortilla to engulf the mixture and created what looks like an enclosed burrito. CAUTION: Make sure to roll the leaf tight enough to where the dolmas will not fall apart when picked up to eat. The whole purpose of wrapping the mixture is to keep it together, like a cigar, and have the flavor of the grape leaves compliment the roll as well. After rolling all the mixture into the leaves, take your rolls and place them in the steamer pot. Add water in the steamer cover to preserve moisture and let them sit for 30-45 minutes, or until rice is cooked. Remove dolmas from steamer and immediately pour lemon juice onto the leaves and place in refrigerator to serve cold, or even at room temperature if pressed for time.  Kibbeh Ingredients: 2 lbs lean ground lamb (or substitute with lean ground beef) ½ cup bulgar (cracked wheat) ¼ teaspoon cinnamon 1 teaspoon salt frying pan teaspoon pepper olive oil 1 teaspoon allspice cutting board and knife ¼ teaspoon ground cumin 2 mixing bowls 2 medium sized onions paper towels and plate ½ cup pine nuts 2 cups water Make sure your meat is thawed out and fresh.  Take the bulgar and water like before, place in small bowl and let sit for 15-20 minutes or depending on the absorbency rate of the cracked wheat.  Begin cutting your onions, some minced and some chopped, and set aside.  NOTE: The following step is optional; as you may either cook the ingredients 	all together at once, or lightly pan fry piece by piece.  Take your frying pan, set on medium heat. Add a teaspoon of olive oil, and lightly brown the onions and pine nuts. Be careful not to burn as they will be cooked again into the meat. Remove onions and pine nuts and let cool. Return to your bulgar after the allotted time and strain any excess water from the cracked wheat and set aside.  Now, in the other mixing bowl, combine salt, pepper, all spice (or kibbeh all spices that may be found at local Arabic store or market), and ground cumin.  At this point, your bulgar is prepared, your meat is thawed, your spices are mixed and the onions and pine nuts are either ready for cooking or have already been lightly browned. Take a handful of meat, like you were making a hamburger patty and mix onions, pine nuts, bulgar and spices into the meat. Very similar to seasoning hamburgers or any other types of meat. Keep rolling the ingredients and press the meat lightly together as it’s sometimes difficult to mix these ingredients into your lamb or beef. The size of each kibbeh “patty” is to your own choice, but keep in mind the thicker the meat, the longer the time it takes to cook. Your oven should be set on medium-high now, ready to pan fry lots of meat.  NOTE: Some kibbeh recipes opt for baking the meat instead of pan frying, while others are form their meat entirely different, almost in the shape of a torpedo – filled with spices and then deep fried. This recipe is clearly not the only means of cooking kibbeh. Be reminded this is only one method. Place two teaspoons of olive oil into the pan, or a little less depending on the size as you do not want to soak the meat in too much oil. Take about four patties of meat, or however many your pan will contain, and begin to pan fry the patties. Occasionally roll the patty over from side to side, in order to cook the meat thoroughly and flake the remaining spices over the meat while its cooking.  The meat will brown very dark, almost like its burnt but this is the cumin, all spice and cinnamon darkening the meat. However, if its turning black or smoking, or smells like its burning, you are obviously running the meat and need to lower the heat of the oven or add more oil for moisture. Take your plate, and place a few paper towels over the plate to cover it and set close to the stove.  After each patty is finished, place the meat onto the paper towels to let excess oils strain from the kibbeh. Let cool, but serve while its still hot. Often kibbeh is served with plan yogurt, or homemade style yogurt that dates back centuries. Preparing a full Lebanese dinner, especially for beginners, is no easy task. Often the hardest part is gathering all the materials together. Be reminded that appearance is not essential for this kind of food, granted you do not want to look unappetizing or spoiled, but taste is much more important. Be patient when cooking these foods, and take your time. Perhaps try making each dish separately before taking the ambition to cook all four recipes all at once. Or make it an evening affair and invite your friends over to try something new. But, once you are accustomed to the routine and demand of cooking and baking Lebanese cuisine, you will have no problems adjusting to other styles of Mediterranean foods and become eager to know more. Baklava Ingredients: 1 lb frozen phyllo sheets 1 cup melted butter 2 cups finely chopped walnuts 2 cups finely chopped blanched almonds 3 cups sugar ½ teaspoon ground cinnamon ¾ cup honey 1 tablespoon lemon juice One large baking pan One mixing bowl One large knife,One boiling pot Lightly grease baking pan with butter, if you forget this step, your dessert will be ruined, as the phyllo sheets will stick to the pan. Also pre-heat your oven to 400 degrees. Thaw phyllo pastry, and taking four sheets of the pastry, use the melted butter to brush and soften each sheet. Place half of the butter brushed sheets into baking pan. Mix nuts, ½ cup sugar and cinnamon in a bowl. Sprinkle  a third of the mixture over pastry sheets lying in the baking pan. Take an additional two phyllo pastry sheets and brush them with butter like before, and place the remaining sheets above the mixture poured into the baking pan.  Continue to add another layer of more nut and sugar mixture. Repeat steps 4 and 5 until there are only four remaining phyllo sheets. Taking the last four phyllo sheets, brush them with butter, except for the top layer and place them into the baking pan and tuck away any overlapping.  Take a large knife and cut the sheet into squares, traditional diamond shaped pieces.  Place baking pan into the oven and set time for 30 minutes or until golden brown.  While the dessert is in the oven, combine ¾ cup sugar, honey, one cup water and lemon juice into pot and wait for it to boil.  Boil baklava syrup for about 20 minutes, occasionally stirring until the consistency is like a maple or waffle syrup like texture.  As soon as the baklava is done, remove it from the oven and immediately pour the syrup all over the dessert.  Allow the baklava to cool about 3-4 hours and to also absorb the syrup before serving and enjoy!
